The claim was published on Facebook on J: 2020, and has been shared more than 1,600 times.
The Burmese: language post's caption translates to English as "The dried butterfly pea flower [Aung Mae Nyo in Burmese] is spreading liver cancer throughout Myanmar."
Expert opinions from Dr: William G Cance, the chief medical officer for the American Cancer Society, and Dr. Ruth Lunn, the director of the US National Toxicology Program's Office of the Report on Carcinogens, state that there is no evidence to support the claim that butterfly pea flowers contain benzene or pose a cancer risk to humans. Professor Khin Maung Win, the physician referenced in the post, also denies making any statements about the health effects of butterfly pea flowers.
